But what we DID know (which seemed mostly ignored in subsequent instalments) was that the number of military ships in Council space was severely limited not by any technical or production limitations, but by treaties that severely limited the number of ships various races could build. So a huge rapid build-up once forewarned of the invasion was on the table.

Max Hoberman had to argue to get the classic arena-style mode in. Bungie didn't really take it seriously though, they all nicknamed Max's version of multiplayer "party game".

Few realize that Halo multiplayer has its roots in Marathon. It's also what first put Bungie on the radar.

>"Gephyrophobia, fear of bridges. Yeah, another map, if I recall, with super verticality. A lot of people fall into this trap, which is people think bigger is better. I mean, hell, it happened even on the warfare stuff we were talking about for Halo 2 in some ways. Its just not always the case. In a lot of those maps they had this mandate, and I don’t remember where it came from, but we had to do bigger because bigger is better." -Max Hoberman

Max and his team kept working on Halo 2's multiplayer while everything else fell apart. The people working on Warzone ended up getting nowhere so Bungie decided by dump it and make Max's multiplayer mode the Halo 2/3 multiplayer.

After Halo 3, Max Hoberman and Jaime Griesemer left Bungie and Sage Merrill became Gameplay Design Lead for Reach/Destiny (lol remember when everyone blamed him back then)

threads.com: So I've recently been playing Civ 5 and have been having a blast. What other games in the series are worth a visit? I often hear 4 is the best and am curious as to why.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>619254221
Honestly Civ 6 is my favorite. I started with 5 and tried out revolution, but if you want straight up depth of mechanics, Civ 6 beats out all of the others by far. 5 was the first one to do hex grid, which I prefer, before that it was square grid. My main gripe with 5 is it seemed like expansion was a trap, you could do just as much with one city if not more than if you expand, it leaves you slightly open to being knocked out of the game but if you manage a decent sized army, that threat is basically non existent against the AI. Revolution on the other hand had the problem of being extremely streamlined in my opinion. It felt like they went out of their way to make the game as user friendly and simple as possible while still being a civilization game. That may have been to attract a new audience. But yeah, I would say your first civ experience is probably the best to date IMO.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>619254221
I have played every civ game, from the original civ game through civ vi, including side games like call to power, alpha centauri, colonization, etc. I’ve even played side meier’s pirates. There are things I love about all of them, and things that make it hard to go backwards. Relative to its time, Civ II is still the greatest, IMO,but it would be hard to go back because of the new features that have been introduced.

I love the epic pacing of the older games, because then each new development felt like a major event rather than just a minor development.

I think Civ VI overall is a great installment, but I just wish there was more historical accuracy with the city district and wonders placement. It irks me that buildings and wonders that exist within city walls can only be built out in the countryside. I prefer to play a mod-extended game with extremely long eras and slow progression (more like the longer pacing of the older games, I think), and so I really don’t like how districts appear so early in the game and are so commonplace. Shrines and temples and libraries and many of the wonders were built inside city walls and should still be in the city center. Districts should be rarer, especially early on, like the old national wonders. Some wonders should take up a terrain tile (like Angkor Wat, which is huge), but something like the colosseum or the great lighthouse should not. These existed within city limits.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I think the biggest problem with 3's story is that they didn't have Bingo Morihashi refine Kamiya's scenario. I get the feeling that Kamiya is kind of like a George Lucas or Stan Lee type, where he's got all these over the top and fanciful ideas, but he needs somebody else to reign his ideas in and make them more grounded, so when they're presented they're more focused. I remember watching a video about Bayonetta's story and the author couldn't ever feel that Bayonetta was at risk, because she was always pulling out more and more new never before seen abilities out of thin air when she was cornered by the enemy.

In Bayonetta 3 the other people who worked on the story was the writer of Astral Chain & the director of Bayonetta 3. Astral Chain's story wasn't especially strong, the other games he wrote for aren't memorable (like Mega Man X7 or something). Bayonetta 3's director is a first time director, and I don't think he's especially strong at writing.

Bingo Morihashi is a japanese novelist and he was brought in to take Kamiya's concept and turn it into a proper story, and he did with Bayonetta 2. Bingo also later on wrote the DMC series except for 1 and 5 (maybe the comics and anime too, I can't remember) but the guy knows how to write better than anybody else listed. There was also JP Kellams who left Platinum in 2017 who was previously refining the english script & enochian. I think these two slapped around Kamiya's story until it was good for 1/2, whereas in 3 those guys saw Kamiya as a superior not to clash against.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>619229603
>5 sec later he respawned on my ship and killed me, and then he destroyed our ship
This didn't happen because this isn't how the game works.

Everyone takes 30 seconds on the Ferry in order to respawn, and when you go through the door and load back in, you are placed in one of a set of 8 potential spawn locations on your ship. You cannot respawn in "5 seconds" and you cannot respawn on someone else's ship, period. It's not mechanically possible.

And like every game, getting better is just a matter of practice and learning the specifics about how the game mechanics function, where to shave off time from your reactions or anticipate player's movements and potential plays. You can't just jump into a game like Battlefield or Tarkov or Apex of any other PvP arena and know all the things that experienced players do, so they're going to kick your ass until you work through all the shit you're doing wrong and are able to correct those mistakes.

You can't just go into a game and win, that's not how games work.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>619254843
It's just a natural progression of the game. Navel fights used to be much more common, but over time people realize that it's actually really hard to win them at all because as long as you have a full crew on both ships, unless something major happens, you're likely not going to be able to keep up accurate cannon shots enough to damage a ship faster than it can be repaired. So most ship fights amount to trying to force the other team to make a mistake so you can shut them down.

The fact of the matter is, boarding a ship is the easiest way to force them to make an error, or just keep them from saving themselves because if you board you can stop their repairs, stop their driving, or distract them while they crash or something. There's really no way to change that mechanically, so people will realize it's the fastest way to win a fight, and so they're going to do it.
